title: US SEC and Binance-US have Reached a ‘Settlement Deal’ - Tekedia
content:
The US Security and Exchange Commission – SEC and Binance.US have reached a settlement agreement that will end the lawsuit filed by the regulator against the crypto exchange and its founder Changpeng Zhao. The settlement, which was announced on June 16, 2023, will require Binance.US to pay a $200 million civil penalty and to implement various remedial measures to ensure compliance with the federal securities laws.

The lawsuit, which was filed on June 5, 2023, accused Binance.US and Zhao of operating unregistered securities exchanges, broker-dealers, and clearing agencies; misrepresenting trading controls and oversight on the Binance.US platform; and the unregistered offer and sale of securities, including Binance’s own crypto assets. The SEC also alleged that Zhao and Binance secretly allowed U.S. customers to trade on the Binance.com platform, which was not registered with the SEC, and that they commingled and diverted customer assets to entities owned by Zhao.

The settlement agreement will resolve all the charges brought by the SEC against Binance.US and Zhao, without admitting or denying the allegations. As part of the settlement, Binance.US will cease offering certain crypto products and services to U.S. customers, such as BNB, BUSD, crypto-lending products, and staking-as-a-service programs. Binance.US will also register as a national securities exchange, broker-dealer, and clearing agency with the SEC, and will submit to regular audits and inspections by the regulator. Binance.US will also establish an independent board of directors and a compliance committee to oversee its operations and ensure adherence to the securities laws.

Zhao, who is also known as CZ, will step down as the CEO of Binance.US and will divest his ownership stake in the company. He will also cooperate with the SEC in any ongoing or future investigations or enforcement actions related to Binance.com or other entities he controls. Zhao will also refrain from participating in any activities involving securities offerings or trading in the U.S.

Binance has struck a deal with the Securities and Exchange Commission that will allow it to continue operating in the U.S. and protect customer assets amid an ongoing lawsuit between the two over Binance’s alleged misuse of customer funds, The New York Times reports. The agreement, which needs approval from a federal judge, will only give U.S. employees access to customers’ private wallet keys and not any international officials, including founder Changpeng Zhao. The news comes a week after Binance.US told customers to withdraw their U.S. dollars after the SEC was pushing for an asset freeze. (LinkedIn News)

The SEC’s Chair Gary Gensler praised the settlement as a “significant achievement” for the protection of investors and the integrity of the crypto markets. He said that the SEC will continue to pursue enforcement actions against entities that violate the securities laws and put investors at risk. He also urged other crypto platforms to register with the SEC and comply with the regulatory framework.

Binance.US’s new CEO Brian Brooks said that the settlement marks a “new chapter” for the company and its customers. He said that Binance.US is committed to providing a safe and compliant platform for crypto trading and innovation in the U.S. He also thanked Zhao for his leadership and vision in creating Binance.US. The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

The settlement deal is a major blow to Binance, which is the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the world by trading volume. Binance has been under intense scrutiny from regulators around the world, who have accused it of facilitating money laundering, tax evasion, and other illicit activities. Binance has also faced lawsuits from investors who claim they lost money due to Binance’s negligence or fraud.

However, the settlement deal is also not investor friendly. It leaves many questions unanswered about the legal status of Binance’s tokens and services, and the rights and remedies of its customers. For example, what will happen to the funds and assets of US customers who have accounts on Binance? Will they be able to withdraw them or transfer them to another platform?

How will they be compensated for any losses or damages caused by Binance’s actions or inactions?

title: Sister Wives’ Meri Brown is ‘rarely’ at her Utah inn after ex Kody helped her move into property following... - The US Sun
content:
MISSING MERI Sister Wives’ Meri Brown is ‘rarely’ at her Utah inn after ex Kody helped her move into property following split

SISTER Wives' Meri Brown has been 'rarely' spotted at her Utah inn after ex Kody helped her move, The U.S. Sun can exclusively reveal.

The reality star had moved into her bed and breakfast in April with help from Kody Brown, The U.S. Sun had revealed at the time.

6 Meri Brown is 'rarely' seen at her bed and breakfast in Utah, according to sources Credit: Instagram / therealmeribrown

6 The Sister Wives star reportedly moved into the inn in April Credit: TLC

6 Lizzie's Heritage Inn is located in the small town of Parowan, Utah Credit: The US Sun

Now, it appears that she "rarely" spends time at the Parowan, Utah, property, according to multiple sources.

One insider told The U.S. Sun: "Meri isn't at Lizzie's Heritage Inn as much as people think.

"She travels a lot, she's always traveling."

The source went on to question whether the TV personality "tricks" her followers into thinking that she's at the Inn by sharing pics of the property or footage making it appear like she is there, but in reality, she's not.

Another insider added: "Meri hasn't been at the inn in quite some time. It's hard to believe she's permanently moved in."

One other local insider revealed that Meri, 52, is not so known around the town of Parowan because she's not a frequent visitor at some of the main spots downtown.

OUT AND ABOUT

The Sister Wives star has posted videos from her car in the last few days while out on the road.

Her latest message to her fans was as follows: "When you're lost, or the road of life has taken you down an unknown road, just stop!

"Stop so you can redirect. Stop so you can make a new plan. Just pause for a moment to reset your inner GPS and get going on your new path to your amazing new destination!"

Last month, Meri spent a week in London where she spent half the time with a group and the other half by herself.

She captioned a series of photos abroad: "The first four days of this trip I was with a group, but the last three I went solo.

"Have you ever done that? It's quite empowering, especially in another country!"

In the new pics, she flaunted her weight loss, showing off her thin face and high cheekbones.

NEXT CHAPTER

Four months after announcing her split from the family's patriarch, the reality star moved from Arizona to Utah with help from Kody.

At the end of April, Meri and Kody were spotted by fans at a gas stop picking up food along the way to Utah.

The duo was driving a large moving truck, per a Reddit post, and then seen at Meri's Lizzie's Heritage Inn moving furniture and a piano.

According to another Reddit post, a camera crew filmed the entire move.

A source told The U.S. Sun: "She's done having anything to do with Arizona.

"She's moving on. Kody has been helpful with her move and supportive of her decision."

Around the same time, The U.S. Sun had reported that her four-bedroom, four-bath home that she was renting in Flagstaff for nearly four years was put up for rent.

Located close to the downtown area, the 4,000 sq ft house - that costs over $1million - could be rented for $4,500 per month.

SEPARATE LIVES

After the Sister Wives divorced Kody in the last season of the hit TLC show, the ladies have been living separate lives.

Kody remains in Flagstaff with Robyn Brown and their children, while Meri is in Utah and Christine Brown, who got engaged to fiance David Woolley, recently bought a new home in Lehi, Utah.

Janelle, who is normally based in Arizona, has been traveling around with her RV and has spent some time with bestie Christine.

A friend of Christine's shed some light on Meri's current status with the Sister Wives in a recent interview.

Leonard Reyes, who got married to his husband thanks to Christine officiating their wedding, told The U.S. Sun that his famous pal and Meri "don't really communicate all that much."

He spilled: "You know, I did tell her - I was like, 'Hey, they reach out, they reach out. If they don't, you know, you got to be happy for you and live your life to the fullest now."

This comes after The U.S. Sun exclusively reported the news that Meri will "hardly make any appearances" on the next season of Sister Wives.

6 Meri occasionally posts from Lizzie's Heritage Inn, but a source questioned whether she sometimes 'tricks' fans into believing she's there when she's really not Credit: Lizzie's Heritage Inn

6 A fan captured Kody and Meri together in April while on their way to Utah Credit: Reddit
